translation: How lonely sits the city, once great with people; she has become like a widow. She who was great among the nations, a princess among the provinces, has become a slave.
Weeping, she shall weep in the night, and her tear is upon her cheeks; she has no comforter among all her lovers. All her friends have dealt treacherously with her; they have become her enemies.
Judah has gone into exile because of affliction and because of great servitude; she dwells among the nations, she finds no rest. All her pursuers have overtaken her between the straits.
The ways of Zion mourn, for none come to the appointed feast; all her gates are desolate, her priests sigh, her virgins are afflicted, and she herself is bitter.
Her adversaries have become the head, her enemies prosper; for the LORD has afflicted her for the multitude of her transgressions. Her little ones have gone into captivity before the foe.
And from the daughter of Zion all her splendor has departed; her princes have become like stags that find no pasture, and they have gone without strength before the pursuer.

Jerusalem remembers in the days of her affliction and of her wanderings all her precious things that were hers from days of old, when her people fell into the hand of the adversary and there was none to help her; the adversaries saw her, they mocked at her downfall.
Jerusalem has sinned grievously; therefore she has become as one unclean. All who honored her despise her, because they have seen her nakedness; she also groans and turns back.

Her uncleanness is in her skirts; she did not remember her latter end, and she has come down in astonishing ruin; there is none to comfort her. Behold, O LORD, my affliction, for the enemy has magnified himself.
The adversary has stretched out his hand over all her precious things, for she has seen the nations enter her sanctuary, those whom you commanded that they should not enter into your assembly.
All her people groan, seeking bread; they have given their precious things for food to restore the soul. Look, O LORD, and behold, for I have become despised.
Is it nothing to you, all you who pass by? Look and see if there is any sorrow like my sorrow, which has been dealt to me, which the LORD inflicted on the day of the fierceness of His anger.
From on high He sent fire into my bones, and it prevailed against them; He spread a net for my feet, He turned me back; He has made me desolate and faint all the day.

The yoke of my transgressions is bound by his hand; they are knit together, they have come up upon my neck; he has made my strength to fail; the Lord has delivered me into hands from which I am not able to rise.
The Lord has rejected all my mighty men in my midst; He has summoned against me an appointed time to crush my young men. The Lord has trodden the winepress for the virgin daughter of Judah.
For these things I weep; my eye, my eye runs down with water, because far from me is a comforter to restore my soul. My children are desolate, for the enemy has prevailed.
Zion stretches out her hands; there is none to comfort her. The LORD has commanded concerning Jacob that his adversaries be round about him; Jerusalem has become as an unclean thing among them.
Righteous is the LORD, for I have rebelled against his commandment. Hear now, all peoples, and behold my sorrow: my virgins and my young men have gone into captivity.
I called to my lovers, but they deceived me; my priests and my elders perished in the city, while they sought food for themselves to restore their life.
See, O LORD, for I am in distress; my inward parts are in ferment, my heart is turned within me, for I have grievously rebelled. Abroad the sword bereaves; at home it is like death.
They have heard that I sigh; there is none to comfort me. All my enemies have heard of my calamity; they are glad that you have done it. You have brought the day you proclaimed; let them be as I am.
Let all their wickedness come before you, and deal with them as you have dealt with me for all my transgressions; for my groanings are many, and my heart is faint.
How the Lord has covered the daughter of Zion in His anger with a cloud, He has cast down from heaven to earth the splendor of Israel, and has not remembered His footstool in the day of His anger.

The Lord has swallowed up without mercy all the dwellings of Jacob; in His wrath He has torn down the strongholds of the daughter of Judah, He has cast them down to the ground; He has profaned the kingdom and its princes.
He has cut off in fierce anger every horn of Israel; He has drawn back His right hand from before the enemy, and He has burned in Jacob like a flaming fire that devours all around.
He bent His bow like an enemy, He stood with His right hand like an adversary, and slew all that were pleasant to the eye; in the tent of the daughter of Zion He poured out His fury like fire.

The Lord has become like an enemy; He has swallowed up Israel, He has swallowed up all her palaces, He has destroyed her strongholds, and He has multiplied in the daughter of Judah mourning and lamentation.

And He has violently laid waste His booth like a garden, He has ruined His appointed place; the LORD has caused to be forgotten in Zion the appointed feast and the Sabbath, and in the indignation of His anger He has spurned king and priest.

The Lord has spurned His altar, He has rejected His sanctuary; He has delivered into the hand of the enemy the walls of her palaces. They have raised a shout in the house of the LORD as on a day of appointed feast.

The LORD purposed to destroy the wall of the daughter of Zion; He stretched out the measuring line, He did not turn back His hand from swallowing up; He made rampart and wall lament, together they languished.
Her gates have sunk into the earth; he has destroyed and broken her bars. Her king and her princes are among the nations; there is no law. Her prophets also find no vision from the LORD.

The elders of the daughter of Zion sit upon the ground, they are silent; they have cast dust upon their heads, they have girded themselves with sackcloth; the virgins of Jerusalem have bowed down their heads to the ground.

My eyes are spent with tears, my inward parts are in turmoil, my liver is poured out upon the earth for the ruin of the daughter of my people, when infant and suckling faint in the streets of the city.
To their mothers they say, “Where is grain and wine?” as they faint like the slain in the streets of the city, as their life is poured out into the bosom of their mothers.

What shall I testify for you, what shall I liken to you, O daughter of Jerusalem? What shall I compare to you, that I may comfort you, O virgin daughter of Zion? For great as the sea is your ruin; who shall heal you?
Your prophets have seen for you vanity and folly, and they have not uncovered your iniquity to turn back your captivity, but have seen for you burdens of falsehood and causes of banishment.

All who pass along the way clap their hands at you; they hiss and wag their head at the daughter of Jerusalem, saying, “Is this the city of which they said, ‘The perfection of beauty, the joy of all the earth’?”

All your enemies have opened wide their mouth against you; they hiss and gnash the teeth, they say, “We have swallowed her up; surely this is the day we have waited for; we have found it, we have seen it.”

The LORD has done what He purposed; He has fulfilled His word that He commanded from days of old. He has thrown down and has not spared, and He has made the enemy rejoice over you; He has exalted the horn of your adversaries.
Their heart cried out to the Lord: O wall of the daughter of Zion, let tears run down like a torrent day and night; give yourself no respite, let not the apple of your eye be silent.

Arise, cry out in the night, at the beginning of the watches; pour out your heart like water before the face of the Lord. Lift up your hands to Him for the life of your little ones, who faint for hunger at the head of every street.
See, O LORD, and look, to whom You have done thus. Should women eat the fruit of their womb, the children of their tender care? Should priest and prophet be slain in the sanctuary of the Lord?
They lie on the ground in the streets, both young and old; my virgins and my young men have fallen by the sword. You have slain them in the day of Your anger; You have slaughtered and not spared.

You have called, as on a day of appointed feast, my terrors on every side; and there was none in the day of the LORD’s anger that escaped or survived. Those whom I have nursed and brought up my enemy has consumed.
I am the man who has seen affliction by the rod of His wrath.
He has led me and made me walk in darkness and not in light.
Surely against me he turns his hand again and again all the day.
He has worn away my flesh and my skin; He has broken my bones.
He has built against me and surrounded me with bitterness and hardship.
He has made me dwell in dark places, like those who are long dead.
He has hedged me about so that I cannot go out; he has made my chains heavy.
Even when I cry out and call for help, he shuts out my prayer.
He has walled up my ways with hewn stone; He has made my paths crooked.
He is to me like a lurking bear, like a lion in secret places.
He has turned aside my ways and tore me in pieces; he has made me desolate.
He bent his bow and set me as the target for the arrow.
He has caused the arrows of His quiver to enter into my inward parts.
I have become a laughingstock to all my people, their song all the day.
He has filled me with bitterness, He has saturated me with wormwood.
He has ground my teeth on gravel; He has made me cower in the dust.
You have cast off my soul from peace; I have forgotten what good is.
And I said, My strength is perished, and my hope from the LORD.
Remember my affliction and my homelessness, the wormwood and the gall.
My soul remembers it well and is bowed down within me.
This I recall to my heart; therefore I will hope.
It is of the lovingkindnesses of the LORD that we are not consumed, for His compassions do not fail.
They are new every morning; great is Your faithfulness.
“The LORD is my portion,” says my soul, “therefore I will hope in Him.”
The LORD is good to those who wait for Him, to the soul that seeks Him.
It is good that one should wait quietly for the salvation of the LORD.
It is good for a man that he bear the yoke in his youth.
Let him sit alone and be silent, for He has laid it upon him.
Let him put his mouth in the dust; perhaps there is hope.
Let him give his cheek to the one who strikes him; let him be filled with reproach.
For the Lord will not cast off forever.
For though He causes grief, yet He will have compassion according to the abundance of His steadfast love.
For he does not afflict from his heart, nor grieve the children of man.
To crush under his feet all the prisoners of the earth
To turn aside the justice of a man before the face of the Most High.
To subvert a man in his cause, the Lord has not seen.
Who is this who speaks and it comes to pass, when the Lord has not commanded it?
Is it not from the mouth of the Most High that evil and good proceed?
Why should a living man complain, a man for the punishment of his sins?
Let us search out and examine our ways, and let us return to the LORD.
Let us lift up our heart with our hands to God in the heavens.
We have transgressed and rebelled; you have not forgiven.
You have covered yourself with anger and pursued us; you have slain without pity.
You have covered Yourself with a cloud, so that prayer cannot pass through.
You have made us scum and refuse in the midst of the peoples.
All our enemies have opened their mouth wide against us.
Terror and pit have come upon us, desolation and ruin.
Streams of water run down my eye because of the ruin of the daughter of my people.
My eye pours down and does not cease, without any respite.
Till the LORD look down and see from heaven.
My eye brings grief to my soul because of all the daughters of my city.
My enemies have hunted me down like a bird, without cause.
They have cut off my life in the pit, and cast a stone upon me.
Waters flowed over my head; I said, I am cut off.
I called on Your name, O LORD, from the lowest pit.
You have heard my voice; do not hide your ear at my sighing, at my cry.
You drew near in the day that I called upon You; You said, “Do not fear.”
You have pleaded, O Lord, the causes of my soul; you have redeemed my life.
You have seen, O LORD, my wrong; judge my cause.
You have seen all their vengeance, all their devices against me.
You have heard their reproach, O LORD, all their thoughts against me.
The lips of those who rise up against me and their whispering are against me all the day.
Look upon their sitting down and their rising up; I am their song.
You will repay them, O LORD, according to the work of their hands.
You will give them hardness of heart; your curse be upon them.
Pursue them in anger and destroy them from under the heavens of the LORD.
How the gold has grown dim, how the fine gold is changed! The holy stones are poured out at the head of every street.
The precious sons of Zion, comparable to fine gold, how they are reckoned as earthen pots, the work of the hands of a potter.
Even sea monsters draw out the breast, they nurse their young; the daughter of my people has become cruel, like ostriches in the wilderness.
The tongue of the nursing infant clings to its palate for thirst; the little children ask for bread, no one breaks it for them.
Those who ate delicacies lie desolate in the streets; those reared in scarlet embrace ash heaps.
For the iniquity of the daughter of my people is greater than the sin of Sodom, which was overthrown in a moment, and no hands were laid on her.
Her Nazirites were purer than snow, they were whiter than milk; they were more ruddy in body than rubies, their form was like sapphire.
Darker than black is their visage; they are not recognized in the streets. Their skin clings to their bones, it is dried up, it has become like wood.
Better were the slain of the sword than the slain of hunger, for these pine away, pierced through, for lack of the fruits of the field.
The hands of compassionate women have boiled their own children; they became their food in the destruction of the daughter of my people.
The LORD has accomplished His fury, He has poured out the fierceness of His anger; and He has kindled a fire in Zion, and it has devoured her foundations.
The kings of the earth did not believe, nor all the inhabitants of the world, that the adversary and the enemy would enter into the gates of Jerusalem.
Because of the sins of her prophets, the iniquities of her priests, who shed in her midst the blood of the righteous.
They wandered blind in the streets, they were defiled with blood, so that none could touch their garments.
“Turn away! Unclean!” they cried to them. “Turn away, turn away, do not touch!” For they fled, they also wandered; they said among the nations, “They shall no more sojourn here.”
The face of the LORD has scattered them; He will no more regard them. They did not respect the faces of the priests; they showed no favor to the elders.
Still our eyes fail, watching in vain for our help; in our watching we have watched for a nation that could not save.
They hunted our steps so that we could not walk in our streets; our end drew near, our days were fulfilled, for our end had come.
Swifter were our pursuers than the eagles of the heavens; upon the mountains they hotly chased us, in the wilderness they lay in wait for us.
The breath of our nostrils, the anointed of the LORD, was captured in their pits, of whom we said, Under his shadow we shall live among the nations.
Rejoice and be glad, O daughter of Edom, you who dwell in the land of Uz; the cup also shall pass to you, you shall be drunk and stripped bare.
The punishment of your iniquity is accomplished, O daughter of Zion; he will no more carry you away into captivity. He has visited your iniquity, O daughter of Edom; he has laid bare your sins.
Remember, O LORD, what has come upon us; look and behold our reproach.
Our inheritance is turned over to strangers, our houses to foreigners.
We have become orphans, without a father; our mothers are as widows.
Our water we drink for silver; our wood comes to us for a price.
On our necks we are pursued; we are weary and are given no rest.
To Egypt we stretched out the hand, to Assyria, to be satisfied with bread.
Our fathers sinned, and they are no more, and we bear their iniquities.
Servants rule over us; there is none to deliver us out of their hand.
We get our bread at the peril of our lives because of the sword of the wilderness.
Our skin is burned like a furnace because of the searing blasts of famine.
Women in Zion they have humbled, virgins in the cities of Judah.
Princes were hanged by their hand; the faces of the elders were not honored.
Young men bore the millstone, and boys staggered under the wood.
The elders have ceased from the gate, the young men from their music.
The joy of our heart has ceased; our dancing has been turned into mourning.
The crown has fallen from our head; woe now to us, for we have sinned.
For this our heart is faint; for these things our eyes grow dim.
Because of Mount Zion, which lies desolate; foxes prowl upon it.
You, O LORD, sit enthroned forever; Your throne endures from generation to generation.
Why do You forget us forever, forsake us for length of days?
Turn us back to Yourself, O LORD, and we shall return; renew our days as of old.
Unless You have utterly rejected us, and are exceedingly angry with us.
